title: When Heirs Disagree: Handling a Wine or Whiskey Collection in Probate
metaTitle: When Heirs Disagree: Selling Wine or Whiskey in Probate | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: How to sell wine or whiskey when heirs disagree. Covers probate authority, building consensus, interim storage, and avoiding piecemeal sales that reduce value.
summary: When multiple heirs inherit a wine or whiskey collection, disagreements can arise. This guide covers how to handle these situations practically while protecting the collection's value.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
content: First, determine who has authority to make decisions. The executor or administrator of the estate typically handles asset sales. If no executor is appointed yet, wait until the court appoints one.
If heirs disagree about whether to sell, the executor should work toward consensus or follow the will's instructions. Selling often makes sense when heirs cannot agree on who keeps what.
list: Confirm the executor or administrator has authority to sell
Attempt to reach agreement among heirs if possible
Keep the collection in proper storage during discussions
Document the collection with photos and inventory
Get an offer so heirs understand the current value
Submit materials when ready to proceed

sections.heading: What Information Matters for Pricing
content: We provide offers based on what the collection is worth today. This gives all heirs a clear, neutral basis for decisions.
list: Producer names and vintages
Quantities and bottle sizes
Storage history and current conditions
Original packaging or wood cases
Any documentation of provenance or purchase history
Condition notes for any damaged bottles

sections.heading: Common Mistakes to Avoid
content: Piecemeal sales often reduce total value. Selling individual bottles to different buyers is inefficient and may mean lower prices than selling as a collection.
Moving bottles from proper storage during disputes can damage value. Keep the collection stable while decisions are made.
list: Letting heirs pick individual bottles before valuation
Selling piecemeal to multiple buyers
Moving bottles to improper storage during disputes
Waiting too long while paying storage fees
Making decisions without executor authorization

sections.heading: How the Process Works
content: Our process provides a neutral valuation that all parties can review.
list: Submit photos and inventory through our form or text to 213-770-9463

Share the offer with all heirs for discussion

sections.heading: Privacy and Safety Notes
content: The offer we provide is confidential and can be shared among heirs as needed for discussion.
We provide documentation suitable for estate accounting and probate records.
All communications go through the executor or their designated contact. We do not communicate with multiple parties unless directed.

faqs.question: What if heirs want different things?
faqs.answer: The executor has authority to make decisions for the estate. Getting a clear valuation often helps heirs agree on a path forward. Selling and dividing proceeds can be simpler than dividing bottles.

faqs.question: Can one heir buy out the others?
faqs.answer: Yes. Our offer provides a fair market value that can be used as a basis for one heir to buy out others' shares if they prefer to keep the collection.

faqs.question: Should we wait until probate closes?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Executors can often sell estate assets during administration with proper authorization. Consult with the estate attorney about timing.

faqs.question: What if some bottles are more valuable than others?
faqs.answer: We evaluate each bottle individually and can break down our offer by wine or category if that helps with discussions among heirs.

faqs.question: How do we handle storage costs while deciding?
faqs.answer: If the collection is in professional storage with ongoing fees, factor this into timing decisions. We can often complete purchases within two weeks of acceptance.

faqs.question: Can the executor sell without heir agreement?
faqs.answer: Executor authority varies by jurisdiction and will terms. Consult with the estate attorney about the executor's powers and any required approvals.

faqs.question: Do you provide appraisals for estate purposes?
faqs.answer: We provide offers representing what we will pay, which reflects current market value. For formal appraisals for tax or legal purposes, you may need a certified appraiser.
